definition: A depository financial institution offering checking and savings accounts, consumer loans, commercial loans, mortgages, and various financial services to individuals and businesses. Commercial banks are subject to GLBA compliance through multiple federal regulators depending on charter type.
official_description: Federally chartered commercial banks operate under Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) supervision. State-chartered member banks of Federal Reserve System operate under Federal Reserve Board supervision. State-chartered non-member banks operate under FDIC supervision. All commercial banks are subject to GLBA's Financial Privacy Rule, Safeguards Rule, and Pretexting Protection. Must designate Privacy Officer, maintain information security program, provide privacy notices, implement multi-factor authentication, conduct annual penetration testing, and report breaches to FTC if 500+ individuals affected. Subject to regular GLBA examinations by regulator.

organization_owner: Chartered by OCC (federal), State Banking Commissioner (state member or non-member), subject to oversight by Federal Reserve (member banks) or FDIC (non-member banks)

Must provide privacy notices (initial and annual) to all members. Must implement comprehensive information security program with nine required elements. Must designate qualified individual responsible for information security. Must encrypt all member data at rest and in transit. Must conduct vulnerability assessments and penetration testing. Must provide security awareness training. Must have written incident response plan and breach notification procedures. Subject to NCUA or state regulator GLBA examinations.
